title: Applicable Scenarios for HDR Mode
answer:
**Applicable Scenarios for HDR Mode** **‚ùÄWhy should we use HDR mode?** We see things with our eyes and process what we see with our brains. Speaking from many aspects, human sight is more advanced than the cameras on high-end smartphones. Human eyes can sense a wide dynamic range, while digital cameras' capabilities in this area are limited. That's why when you take photos in scenes with high contrast, the bright areas may look white and the dark areas may look black (depending on the exposure you set). Below is a photo taken using P7 in normal mode. In the scene with high contrast, areas with light are white, and those without light are black. ![](http://consumer.huawei.com/support/servlet/imageServlet?dlType=SupportImage&imagePath=/20150601203551448001.jpg) In HDR mode, you can take photos with effects closer to what you see. The following figure is taken in HDR mode. ![](http://consumer.huawei.com/support/servlet/imageServlet?dlType=SupportImage&imagePath=/20150601203627706001.jpg)

It is the same scene, but with much better bright and dark details.

The following are more examples of photos taken in HDR mode.

![](http://consumer.huawei.com/support/servlet/imageServlet?dlType=SupportImage&imagePath=/20150601203653988001.jpg)

![](http://consumer.huawei.com/support/servlet/imageServlet?dlType=SupportImage&imagePath=/20150601203733828001.jpg)

How can we turn on HDR mode?

The P7 is used an example. Open the camera, go to the mode menu, and turn on HDR.

However, you are not advised to always use HDR mode.

**When should we use and not use HDR mode?**

You are advised to turn on HDR mode only when necessary, for example, when the scene you are capturing has very bright and very dark areas, or if the object you are shooting is covered by shadow. If HDR mode is turned on when not required, it may decrease the photo's contrast and shadow and make the photo effects unnatural.

Avoid shooting moving objects in HDR mode. Multiple photos need to be taken to combine into one HDR photo. Therefore, every movement of the shooting object may lead to stitching defects or blurred images. When using HDR mode, keep the shooting object as steady as possible.

HDR mode is not applicable to taking snapshots, because your phone needs time to process HDR photos and you will not be able to take another photo in a short period of time. Turn off HDR mode if you want to take multiple photos consecutively.
